error.signature: Warning: Encountered two children with the same key, `keyValue`. Keys should be unique so that components maintain their identity across updates.
error.regex: Encountered two children with the same key|Duplicate key|Keys should be unique

verdict.summary: Two or more sibling elements in a list have the same key prop. React uses keys for reconciliation; duplicates cause incorrect DOM updates, lost state, and stale UI.

dead_ends.action: Use array index as the key
dead_ends.why_fails: Index keys cause state bugs when items are reordered, inserted, or deleted. React cannot distinguish moved items from new ones.
dead_ends.condition: When the list is dynamic (items can be added, removed, or reordered)

dead_ends.action: Use Math.random() or Date.now() as key
dead_ends.why_fails: Generates a new key every render, destroying and recreating all components each time. Kills performance and loses all component state.

workarounds.action: Use a unique, stable identifier from the data as the key (e.g., database ID)
Generate stable IDs with crypto.randomUUID() at data creation time, not at render time
workarounds.how: When adding items: setItems([...items, { id: crypto.randomUUID(), ...newItem }])
workarounds.condition: When the data source does not provide unique IDs

leads_to.condition: When attempting to fix duplicate keys by removing keys entirely, triggering the missing key warning

preceded_by.condition: When fixing missing keys by using a non-unique field that has duplicates in the data

frequently_confused_with.distinction: duplicate-key-warning means keys exist but are not unique; each-child-unique-key means the key prop is missing entirely from list items
